faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Find quick answers to common baby care questions

feeding.q: When should I start introducing solid foods?
feeding.a: Most babies are ready for solid foods around 6 months of age. Signs of readiness include sitting up with support, showing interest in food, and losing the tongue-thrust reflex.

feeding.q: How often should I breastfeed my newborn?
feeding.a: Newborns typically need to feed every 2-3 hours, or 8-12 times per day. Follow your baby's hunger cues rather than strict schedules.

feeding.q: How do I know if my baby is getting enough milk?
feeding.a: Look for 6-8 wet diapers a day, steady weight gain, and a baby who seems content after feeding. Your pediatrician will track their growth at checkups.

feeding.q: When can my baby have water?
feeding.a: It's best to wait until your baby is around 6 months old and starting solids. Breast milk or formula provides all the hydration they need before then.

feeding.q: What's the difference between spit-up and vomit?
feeding.a: Spit-up is a gentle flow of milk from your baby's mouth, while vomit is more forceful and involves a larger volume. Frequent, forceful vomiting warrants a call to the doctor.

feeding.q: How should I store expressed breast milk?
feeding.a: Store breast milk in clean bottles or bags. It can be kept at room temperature for up to 4 hours, in the fridge for up to 4 days, or in the freezer for about 6 months.

feeding.q: What foods should I avoid giving my baby?
feeding.a: Avoid honey (before 12 months), whole nuts, hard candies, popcorn, and foods that are choking hazards. Also avoid cow's milk as a drink before 12 months.

sleep.q: How much sleep does my baby need?
sleep.a: Newborns sleep 14-17 hours per day, while 6-12 month olds need 12-16 hours including naps. Sleep patterns vary greatly between babies.

sleep.q: What is a good bedtime routine?
sleep.a: A simple, calming routine can help signal it's time to sleep. Try a warm bath, a gentle massage, reading a short story, or singing a lullaby.

sleep.q: When will my baby sleep through the night?
sleep.a: Most babies can sleep through the night (6-8 hours) by 3-6 months, but this varies. Some may take longer, and that's completely normal.

sleep.q: Is it safe for my baby to sleep on their stomach?
sleep.a: No, always place babies on their back to sleep to reduce the risk of SIDS. Once they can roll over on their own, it's okay if they choose to sleep on their stomach.

sleep.q: When should I stop swaddling my baby?
sleep.a: Stop swaddling when your baby shows signs of rolling over, which is usually around 2-4 months. Transition to a sleep sack for safety.

sleep.q: How do I handle sleep regressions?
sleep.a: Sleep regressions are normal and often linked to growth spurts or developmental milestones. Stick to your routine, offer extra comfort, and it should pass in a few weeks.

development.q: When should my baby start crawling?
development.a: Most babies start crawling between 6-10 months. Some babies skip crawling entirely and go straight to walking, which is also normal.
Tummy time helps strengthen your baby's neck and shoulder muscles, which are crucial for rolling over and crawling. It also helps prevent a flat spot on their head.

development.q: How can I help with teething pain?
development.a: Offer a solid, chilled teething toy or a cool, wet washcloth. Gently massaging their gums with a clean finger can also provide relief.

development.q: When do babies typically say their first words?
development.a: First words usually appear between 10-14 months. 'Mama' and 'dada' are often among the first words, though they may not be used meaningfully at first.

development.q: Should I worry if my baby isn't hitting milestones?
development.a: Babies develop at their own pace, and there's a wide range of normal. However, if you have concerns about a significant delay, always discuss it with your pediatrician.

development.q: How can I encourage my baby's development?
development.a: Talk, read, and sing to your baby regularly. Provide tummy time, offer age-appropriate toys, and respond to their cues and attempts at communication.

health.q: When should I call the pediatrician?
health.a: Call for fever over 100.4¬∞F (38¬∞C) in a newborn, difficulty breathing, persistent vomiting, signs of dehydration, or if you're concerned about any changes in behavior.

health.q: How often should I bathe my baby?
health.a: A full bath 2-3 times a week is usually enough for a baby in the first year. Too much bathing can dry out their sensitive skin.

health.q: What should I do for a diaper rash?
health.a: Change diapers frequently, clean the area gently with water, and allow it to air dry. Apply a thick layer of zinc oxide diaper cream for protection.

health.q: How do I care for the umbilical cord stump?
health.a: Keep the stump clean and dry until it falls off on its own, usually within 1-2 weeks. Fold the diaper down to expose it to air and give sponge baths until it has healed.

health.q: How often should my baby have checkups?
health.a: Regular checkups are typically at birth, 3-5 days, 2 weeks, and then at 2, 4, 6, 9, and 12 months during the first year.

health.q: What vaccines does my baby need?
health.a: Follow the CDC vaccination schedule, which includes vaccines for hepatitis B, DTaP, Hib, PCV, IPV, rotavirus, and others. Your pediatrician will guide you.

interaction.heading: Interaction Tips by Age
interaction.subheading: Discover meaningful ways to engage with your baby

0_3.title: 0‚Äì3 Months
tips: ‚Æû Make eye contact and smile often
‚Æû Talk softly and describe what you're doing
‚Æû Hold baby close during feeding times
‚Æû Respond to their coos and sounds

feeding.title: Feeding: Tips and Schedule
feeding.subtitle: Track your baby's feeding times and learn best practices with our intuitive interface.
feeding.errorLoading: Failed to load schedules. Please try again later.

feedingtips.title: Feeding Tips
feedingtips.subtitle: Essential guidance for safe and healthy feeding

categories.title: General Feeding Tips
tips: ‚Æû Always feed in a calm, comfortable setting.
‚Æû Watch for hunger cues rather than sticking to strict schedules.
‚Æû Burp your baby after every feed.
‚Æû Do not add cereal to bottles unless prescribed.
‚Æû Gradually introduce one solid food at a time after 6 months.
‚Æû Ensure baby stays upright during and after feeding.
‚Æû Keep hydrated ‚Äì breast milk or formula covers hydration until 6 months.
‚Æû Trust your baby's appetite ‚Äì don't force-feed.

categories.title: Feeding Cautions & Notes
tips: ‚Æû Do not feed cow's milk before 1 year.
‚Æû Avoid choking hazards ‚Äì no nuts, grapes, or raw carrots early on.
‚Æû Don't prop bottles or leave baby unattended.
‚Æû Limit juice; it's not necessary for infants.
‚Æû Watch for food allergies ‚Äì introduce one new food every 3 days.
‚Æû No added salt or sugar in baby foods.
‚Æû Avoid overfeeding ‚Äì look for satiety signs.
‚Æû Breastfeeding mothers should monitor their diet too.

feedingtips.ageTipsSubtitle: Age-appropriate feeding guidance for your baby

ageBasedTips.title: 0‚Äì3 Months
tips: ‚Æû Feed every 2‚Äì3 hours, or 8‚Äì12 times per day.
‚Æû Watch for hunger cues: rooting, sucking motions.
‚Æû No water or solid foods needed yet.
‚Æû Feed on demand, not by strict schedule.
‚Æû Keep track of feeding times and sides.

ageBasedTips.title: 4‚Äì6 Months
tips: ‚Æû Continue breast milk or formula as main nutrition.
‚Æû May begin solid foods if showing readiness signs.
‚Æû Introduce one new food at a time.
‚Æû Look for signs of food allergies.
‚Æû Use proper consistency - very runny at first.
‚Æû Never force feed - follow baby's cues.

ageBasedTips.title: 7‚Äì9 Months
tips: ‚Æû Offer soft, small pieces of food.

ageBasedTips.title: 10‚Äì12 Months
tips: ‚Æû Avoid foods that are choking hazards.

sleep.sleepDescription: Track your baby‚Äôs naps, nighttime sleep, and moods after rest.

0_3.title: 0‚Äì3 Months
tips: ‚Æû Newborns sleep ~14‚Äì17 hours/day in short stretches.
‚Æû No fixed routine ‚Äî follow baby's natural rhythm.
‚Æû Feed-sleep cycles dominate at this stage.
‚Æû Place baby on their back to sleep.
‚Æû Respond calmly to night wakings ‚Äî it's normal.
‚Æû Use dim lights at night to help differentiate day/night.
‚Æû Burp gently before laying baby down.
‚Æû Track sleep patterns to understand habits early on.

4_6.title: 4‚Äì6 Months
tips: ‚Æû Begin a consistent bedtime routine (bath, book, lullaby).
‚Æû Baby may sleep 6‚Äì8 hour stretches at night.
‚Æû Transition from 3‚Äì4 naps to 2‚Äì3 naps daily.
‚Æû Start sleep training gently if needed.
‚Æû Use blackout curtains for better naps.
‚Æû Avoid late-evening naps ‚Äî they can delay bedtime.
‚Æû Watch for sleep cues: rubbing eyes, yawning, fussiness.
‚Æû Allow time for baby to self-soothe before intervening.
‚Æû No need for feeding every time they wake up at night.
‚Æû Offer comfort objects like a soft cloth (under supervision).

7_12.title: 7‚Äì12 Months
tips: ‚Æû 2 naps/day are common at this stage.
‚Æû Avoid stimulating play just before bedtime.
‚Æû Use bedtime stories to build consistent wind-down.
‚Æû Reassure during separation anxiety, but stay consistent.
‚Æû Keep night-time interactions quiet and low-energy.
‚Æû Stick to a wake-sleep schedule to build habit.
‚Æû Encourage falling asleep in crib (not in arms).

growthCategory.title: WHO Growth Standards Comparison
growthCategory.subtitle: Based on WHO Child Growth Standards 2006 (50th percentile)

actions.continue: Continue current feeding and care routine
actions.nutrition: Keep balanced nutrition with appropriate portions

statusMessages.perfect: Your baby's {{measurementName}} ({{measurement}}{{unit}}) is perfectly aligned with WHO standards for {{genderText}} at {{ageText}}. This indicates optimal growth conditions.
statusMessages.excellent: Your baby's {{measurementName}} is excellent and within the healthy WHO range for {{genderText}} at {{ageText}}. Growth is on track.

growthCategory.heightAnalysisTitleMale: Official WHO Height Standards for Boys Height Analysis
growthCategory.heightAnalysisTitleFemale: Official WHO Height Standards for Girls Height Analysis

percentileInfo.title: Understanding Percentiles:
percentileInfo.description: The 50th percentile represents the median (average). 25th-75th percentile is considered normal range. Below 5th or above 95th percentile may require medical attention.

noData.title: No Growth Data Yet
noData.description: Add some growth measurements above to see your baby's progress compared to WHO standards.
noData.note: Only real measurements will be displayed - no dummy data.

growthCategory.whoDescription: The WHO Child Growth Standards describe how children should grow under optimal conditions. These charts show the 50th percentile (median) values based on data from healthy, breastfed children from diverse populations worldwide. Normal growth typically falls within the 3rd to 97th percentiles.

disclaimer.educational: This chart uses official WHO Child Growth Standards 2006 and is for educational purposes only. It should not replace professional medical advice or diagnosis.
disclaimer.medical: Always consult with your pediatrician for personalized guidance on your baby's growth and development. In case of concerning measurements, seek professional medical evaluation promptly.
